Module kivakit.core
Package com.telenav.kivakit.core.function

Class Maybe<Value>

java.lang.Object
com.telenav.kivakit.core.function.Maybe<Value>
All Implemented Interfaces:
SilentTryTrait, Presence
Direct Known Subclasses:
Result
public class Maybe<Value> extends Object implements Presence, SilentTryTrait
A substitute for Optional that adds functionality and integrates with Repeater

Construction

A Maybe can be constructed in three ways:

  1. absent() - Creates a Maybe whose value is missing
  2. maybe(Object) - Creates a Maybe whose value can be missing or not
  3. present(Object) - Creates a Maybe whose value is always non-null

Terminal Operations

  • isPresent() - Returns true if a value is present
  • isAbsent() - Returns true if no value is present
  • get() - Any value that might be present, or null if no value is present
  • has() - Returns true if a value is present
  • orMaybe(Object) - Returns this value, or the default maybe value
  • orDefaultTo(Object) - Returns this value, or the default value
  • orDefaultTo(Source) - Returns this value, or the default value
  • orThrow(String, Object...) - Returns this value or throws an exception
  • orThrow()- Returns this value or throws an exception
  • asStream() - Converts this value to a stream with zero or one element(s)

Functions

  • apply(Function) - Applies the given function to this value
  • then(Function) - Returns the result of applying the given function to this value
  • map(BiFunction, Object) - Returns the result of applying the given two-argument function to this value and the given argument
  • map(TriFunction, Object, Object) - Returns the result of applying the given three-argument function to this value and the given arguments
  • map(TetraFunction, Object, Object, Object) - Returns the result of applying the given four-argument function to this value and the given arguments
  • map(PentaFunction, Object, Object, Object, Object) - Returns the result of applying the given five-argument function to this value and the given arguments
  • map(Function) - Applies the given function to this value

Conditionals

  • absentIf(BooleanFunction) - Applies the given function to this value, returning this value if it is true, or absent() if it is false
  • presentIf(BooleanFunction) - Applies the given function to this value, returning this value if it is true, or absent() if it is false
  • ifPresent(Consumer) - Calls the given consumer if a value is present
  • ifPresentOr(Consumer, UncheckedVoidCode) - Calls the given consumer if a value is present, otherwise calls the given code
Author:
jonathanl (shibo), viniciusluisr
See Also:

    • apply

      public <Output> Maybe<Output> apply(Function<? super Value,? extends Maybe<? extends Output>> function)

      If a value is present, uses the given function to map the value from Value to Maybe<ResultType>. If no value is present, returns absent(). The effect is that of allowing functions to be chained together in a nested structure where each nested function introduces a new lambda variable that is visible to inner functions. For example: 

       var seven = present(7);
 var three = present(3);

 var sum = seven.apply(a ->
               three.apply(b ->
                   present(a + b)))
           .get();

      In this example, if either seven or three had no value present (or both values were absent), the statement would return absent(). Only if both values are present will the statement result in the sum of the two values. This allows us to stop thinking about the special case where one or both values are missing.

      Monadic Terminology

      Note that this method is sometimes referred to as flatMap. However, the name 'flatMap' does not accurately describe what this method does, as it only describes what happens when values are collections.

      Important Note

      Notice that the first sentence of the description for this method is exactly the same as that provided for map(Function). The difference between the two methods is that the function passed to this method produces Maybe<ResultType> directly (which allows function nesting), while the function passed to map(Function) just maps the value to the ResultType type, which is then wrapped in a Maybe.

      Type Parameters:
      Output - The type being mapped to
      Parameters:
      function - A function mapping from Value to Maybe<ResultType>
      Returns:
      The mapped value as a Maybe object, or absent() if no value was present

    • map

      public <ResultType> Maybe<ResultType> map(Function<? super Value,? extends ResultType> mapper)
      If a value is present, uses the given function to map the value from Value to ResultType. The mapped value is then wrapped in a Maybe<ResultType> object and returned. If no value is present, returns absent(). The effect is that of simply mapping this optional value to a new type.

      Important Note

      Notice that the first sentence of the description for this method is exactly the same as that provided for apply(Function). The difference between the two methods is that the function passed to apply(Function) produces Maybe<ResultType> directly (which allows function nesting), while the function passed to this method just maps the value to the ResultType type, which is then wrapped in a Maybe.

      Type Parameters:
      ResultType - The type that Value is being mapped to
      Parameters:
      mapper - A function mapping from Value to ResultType
      Returns:
      The mapped value or absent()

    • map

      public <Argument2, ResultType> Maybe<ResultType> map(BiFunction<Value,Argument2,ResultType> function, Argument2 argument2)
      If a value is present and the given value is not null, applies the given bi-function to produce a result of a different type.
      Parameters:
      function - The bi-function, f(Value, Argument2) -> ResultType
      argument2 - The second argument to pass to the bi-function, along with this value as the first argument
      Returns:
      The combination of this value and the given argument, if both values are non-null, otherwise, returns absent().

    • map

      public <Argument2, Argument3, ResultType> Maybe<ResultType> map(TriFunction<Value,Argument2,Argument3,ResultType> function, Argument2 argument2, Argument3 argument3)
      If a value is present, and the given arguments are non-null, applies the given tri-function to produce a result of a different type.
      Parameters:
      function - The tri-function, f(Value, Argument2, Argument3) -> ResultType
      argument2 - The second argument to pass to the tri-function, along with this value as the first argument
      argument3 - The third argument to pass to the tri-function
      Returns:
      The combination of this value and the given arguments, if all arguments are non-null, otherwise, returns absent().

    • map

      public <Argument2, Argument3, Argument4, ResultType> Maybe<ResultType> map(TetraFunction<Value,Argument2,Argument3,Argument4,ResultType> function, Argument2 argument2, Argument3 argument3, Argument4 argument4)
      If a value is present, and the given value is also present, applies the given tri-function to produce a result of a different type.
      Parameters:
      function - The combining tetra-function, f(Value, Argument2, Argument3, Argument4) -> ResultType
      argument2 - The second argument to pass to the quad-function, along with this value as the first argument
      argument3 - The third argument to pass to the quad-function along with this value
      argument4 - The fourth argument to pass to the quad-function along with this value
      Returns:
      The combination of this value and the given arguments, if all arguments are non-null, otherwise, returns absent().

    • then

      public <Argument2, Argument3, Argument4, Argument5> Maybe<Value> then(PentaFunction<Value,Argument2,Argument3,Argument4,Argument5,Value> function, Argument2 argument2, Argument3 argument3, Argument4 argument4, Argument5 argument5)
      If a value is present, and the given value is also present, applies the given five-argument function to produce a new value of the same type.
